question: Question_06
sols:
Denote \emph{y} as the distance from the top of the bowl to the water
level and \emph{r} the radius of the water surface.

Then, consider a right-angled triangle with a water surface radius
\emph{r} as base, then the height is \emph{y}, and the hypoteneuse is 3,
which is the radius of the bowl. (The top of the triangle is exactly at
the center of the the sphere, half of which becomes the bowl).

Then $r^2 + y^2 = 3^2 = 9$ implies $r^2 = 9-y^2$, so the area of the
water surface is given as a function of \emph{y} by

\[A(y) = r^2 \pi = \pi (9-y^2)\]

A thin slab of water thus has volume $A(y)\triangle y$ and mass

\[M(y) = 1000 A(y)\triangle y = 1000\pi(9-y^2)\triangle y\]

This slab of water travels a distance of \emph{y+2} to be pumped out
(\emph{+2} because of the 2m vertical outlet) and requires a force of
\emph{Mg}

Therefore, summing the work done for each slab, and letting
$\triangle y\to 0$, we get

\begin{align*}
W &= \int_0^3 1000\pi g (2+y)(9-y^2) dy \\
&= 1000\pi g \left[\int_0^3 (18 + 9y -2y^2 -y^3) dy \right]\\
&= 1000\pi g \left[ 18y +9y^2/2 - 2y^3/3 - y^4/4]_0^3 \right]\\
&= 1000\pi g \left( 18\cdot 3 + 9(3^2)/2 - 2(3^3)/3 - 3^4/4\right)
\end{align*}
hints:
What is the shape of the water surface and how does it change during the
process?

To describe this, you need the crucial variable that changes with the
process of pumping.

You can use either the depth of water or the distance from the top of
the bowl to the water level, but the latter will be easier.

Then find a formula for the water surface so that you can find the work
done to lift up a small slab of water from the water surface up to the
top of the bowl and out of the outlet.
